'Group I introns' are large self-splicing ribozymes. They catalyze their own
excision from mRNA, tRNA and rRNA precursors in a wide range of organisms. The core
secondary structure consists of nine paired regions (P1-P9). These
fold to essentially two domains - the P4-P6 domain (formed from the stacking of
P5, P4, P6 and P6a helices) and the P3-P9 domain (formed from the P8, P3, P7 and
P9 helices). The secondary structure mark-up for this family
represents only this conserved core. Group I introns often have long open
reading frames inserted in loop regions.
